CONCEPT.SN: Use for paper made from abaca (Musa textilis) fibers.
Use for tiny circular thin spots in the paper.
Use for defects of small undissolved alum crystals.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers with thicker middles than edges.
Use for ten reams of paper.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a watermark of widely spaced parallel lines.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers showing burn marks on the surface.
Use for pearly, light brown, brittle spots in papers.
Use for bubble-like raised areas in papers, often but not restricted to coated papers.

Types of paper by uses or names
Types of paper by uses or names
Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for highly glazed, inexpensive papers, coated on one side only.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for highly polished calendered papers, coated on one side only; usually used for labels.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for indentations in the surface of coated papers in the shape of brush bristles.
Do not use for the Swedish marbled papers sometimes called British marbled papers.
Use for papers coated on one side, brush polished, with a brilliant surface; usually used for cigar labels and box coverings.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for streaks in the surface of coated papers made by brushes which spread on the coating in the papermaking process.

CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for small wrinkles in the paper parallel to one of the sides.
Use for small oil spots or indentations in the sheet.
Use for papers embossed to imitate canvas.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for strong packing papers containing carbolic acid as an insect repellent.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for soft, unsized, very thin papers, generally made in China from bamboo fibers, used for proofing papers for plate printing, for lithographic prints, and for transfer paper.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers heavily coated, usually on one side only, used in lithography.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for paper displaying blind impressions made by cloth.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers with cloud-shaped patterns created by uneven dispersion of bleached and colored pulps.
Use for papers with unevenness in look-through.
Use for good quality endpapers, decorated in various ways, often drab colored and sprinkled.

Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for any foreign substance in paper, such as sand, feathers, string.
Use for long thin areas of the paper parallel to one of the sides where the fibers have clumped together thickly, causing adjacent thinner areas in look-through.

CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for cracks in the surface of coated papers.
Use for small pits in coated papers.
Use for inexpensive heavy drawing papers or cardboards in various colors with a rough surface on one side, glazed on the other.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names
Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers with surface dyes rubbed off.
Use for areas in paper in which the pulp is pressed so tightly that it produces a mottled or "crowded" appearance in the fibers in look-through.
Use for papers decorated on the surface with a variegated coloration or with the creation of a crinkly pattern.
Use for papers which curl up when placed on a flat surface.

CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Do not use for the sprinkled papers sometimes called Cypress marbled papers.
Use for any dull areas in an otherwise highly glossy surface of a sheet.

CONCEPT.BT: Paper features (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a lithographed paper applied to windows to imitate stained glass.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for wallpapers with small square repeated designs, pictures, or figures, often hand colored.
Use for irregular streaks or long thin lumpy areas on the paper's surface.
Use for papers with different colors, textures, or finish on the two sides.

Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers which flake or powder from loose fibers on the surface.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers generally used for envelopes, in lots of 504 sheets.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers whose deckled edges are quite large and thin.
Use for small round glazed spots in paper.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for reams "of paper supplied flat," i.e. unfolded; see Labarre, 109.
Use for any paper with dirt specks in it.
Use for small bits of paper – usually detached from the edges – that have attached to the surface of the sheet.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for edges that are clumpy or rough.
Use for scratchy or abrasive substances in papers.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for hair-thin cuts in the surface of a sheet where it appears that hairs or long fibers have been pulled out of the surface.
Use for soft-textured papers used for woodcuts.

Types of paper by method of manufacture

CONCEPT.SN: Use for reams "not made up to the full number of a printer's ream, i.e. 516 sheets"; Labarre, 130.
Use for papers decorated within the fibers.
Use for straw-colored, soft, absorbent, unsized, very thin papers, usually used for steel plate or wood engraving and pasted onto a heavier stock.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for "480 sheets or 20 inside quires of 24 [good] sheets each"; Labarre, 222.
Use for a thick, sturdy, long-fibered, cloudy paper, usually in a cream or natural color.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a thin, strong, durable, long-fibered paper.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a coarse, heavy wood-pulp paper, usually brown, used for bags, wrapping, or envelopes.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a white, usually wood-pulp paper, used to make doilies, valentines, or box laces.

CONCEPT.SN: Always subdivide this term by the dimensions of the leaf in inches, citing height then width. For example: 655 Leaf sizes (Paper) |x 24" by 36". |2 rbpap; if the leaf has been trimmed, this should be noted in a copy- specific note.
CONCEPT.BT: Paper sizes (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for any paper with a mechanically produced grain which looks like leather, usually used over boards in binding.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: A leaf is one half of a folded sheet; i.e. 2 pages.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers decorated with a lithographed design.
Use for papers suitable for lithographic printing.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for very sturdy, high quality, sized, wove papers.

Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for thin papers used for copies, interleaving with carbon papers, usually for typewriter use.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names
Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for very fancy, usually decorated, coated papers containing ground mica in their sizing; may be dyed, calendered, or embossed, and are often shellacked to be washable; used in greeting cards, fancy box covers, etc.

Use for handmade papers to designate "two grades of the same paper ... 18 quires of insides or perfect paper, each quire containing 24 sheets, and two quires of outsides or inferior, broken, or damaged paper, of only 20 sheets each, one on top and one on the bottom, making a total of 472"; Labarre, 222.
Use for papers with several colors on the surface or different colored fibers in the same sheet; usually used for boxes.
Use for "an imitation hand-made paper ... made on a cylinder or cylindrical mould revolving in a vat of pulp," Labarre, 167.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by method of manufacture
Types of paper by uses or names
Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for all "below par" qualities of paper emanating from its manufacture, handling, storage, treatment, or materials.

CONCEPT.SN: Use, preferably with subdivisions, to identify noteworthy paper features which cannot be otherwise classified using terms on this list.

CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term, do not use; index under narrower term.

CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term, do not use; index under narrower term.
Use for a sturdy French mould-made paper for drawing, especially with charcoal or crayon.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for paper manufactured to simulate parchment.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a greaseproof wrapping paper.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers whose surfaces have been embossed with a tiny pattern; often done to halftone engraved papers or shiny cover stock to reduce the shininess and soften the photographic effect.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a glazed greaseproof wrapping paper.

Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a featherweight paper with fibers too loosely pressed, yielding a light, weak sheet easy to tear.
Use for thick, soft, high-quality (usually linen or cotton) printing papers, especially for use in engraving or wood block printing.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for spots on coated papers that have been rubbed or pulled off in the paper's manufacture.
Use for thick transparent paper which looks like celluloid, especially used for greeting cards.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for "21 1/2 quires of 24 good sheets, i.e. 516 in all"; Labarre, 222.
Use for papers primarily used for programs, especially a soft, relatively unsized paper that makes little noise when folded or crinkled.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a fourth of a folio ream, "the result of cutting a flat ream into quarto sheets ... and packing these in 500s"; Labarre, 217.
Use for "paper ruled or pressed on the surface, or in watermark, with small squares"; Labarre, 217; especially used in philately or drafting.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for 24 sheets.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for cheap buff-colored paper.

Paper quantities (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers with a ribbed surface.
Use as a general term to designate any defective hand-made papers.
Use for papers "cut from the pith of a small tree" from Formosa; Dictionary of Paper, 372; do not use as a designation for oriental handmade papers.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for longitudinal wrinkles in coated paper.
Use for high-quality papers used for bonds, stocks, or other certificates, often with a distinctive feature in them for safety, to prevent counterfeiting.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for small marks visible where watermarks are sewn to the mould.
Use for a kind of multi-leveled watermark revealing a picture in the paper shaded from light to dark, depending on the varying thicknesses of the sheet within the picture.

Use for full sheets of paper, such as in broadsides or as sheets in a ream. Always subdivide this term by the the dimensions of the sheet in inches, citing height then width. For example: 655 Sheet sizes (Paper) |x 24" by 36". |2 rbpap; if the sheet has been trimmed, this should be stated in a copy-specific note.
CONCEPT.BT: Paper sizes (Gathering term; do not assign)
Paper quantities (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for tiny, hard, light-reflective particles in the paper; these may fall or be scratched out of the sheet, usually leaving pinholes.
Use for a silver-colored coated paper.

Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for sheets where the coating is lacking in places, having been unevenly applied.
Use for ruptured spots at the edges of machine-made papers.
Use for spots in paper caused by a fungus or bacterial growth.
Use for small splinters of wood in paper.
Use for streaks or snake-like marks on the surface of a sheet.
Use for any paper that is too compressible or ink absorbent for its intended purpose.
Used in the United States to designate 500 sheets.

CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names
Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for paper made from straw fibers.

Designations of paper weights are generally given in pounds in terms of weight per ream. "The weight of a ream of a particular size and number of sheets is known as the substance number" (Labarre, 297). Subdivide by the weight of the paper in subfield |x. For example: 655 Substance (Paper) |x 24 lbs. |2 rbpap
CONCEPT.BT: Paper features (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for papers decorated with wave-like patterns – sometimes sharp or jagged – usually done in watercolors.
Gathering term, do not use; index under narrower term. Refers to all processes which decorate paper solely on the surface; more than one process may be used on a single paper.

Gathering term, do not use; index under narrower term. Use for papers treated with processes which disrupt or enhance the original smoothness of the paper; these treatments can be combined with surface applications.
Do not use for those papers that are designated British marbled papers.

CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for watermarks "showing three thicknesses in the same sheet of paper"; Labarre, 304.

Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for what appears to be an added chainline at the edge of the sheet.

CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term, do not use; index under narrower term. The narrower terms are the traditional categories used by papermakers, users, and scholars; these categories are not mutually exclusive.

CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term, do not use; index under narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Types of paper by uses or names
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term, do not use; index under narrower term. Includes names of specific kinds of papers created for specific uses; often, but not always, the use is suggested by the name of the paper, e.g., Currency papers. Many papers' names are arbitrary; some are related to use, content, inventor, manufacturer, color, size, or other feature. The present thesaurus contains only the more common names and includes no commercial brand names. This category does not include decorated papers, since decorations are features of papers.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper (Gathering term; do not assign)
Types of paper by uses or names
Types of paper by presence or absence of sizing

CONCEPT.SN: Use for edges of sheets retaining their original deckles.
Use for small circular thin spots, thicker around the circular edges, where a drop of water has dispersed the fibers in the hand papermaking process.
Use for papers manufactured to simulate real vellum.
CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by uses or names
Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for any pattern in the paper which appears when the paper is held up to the light, and light shines through because the paper is thinner where the pattern is formed. Terms listed here are general designations of types of watermarks, and do not indicate specific shapes or patterns, which can be described in notes in the cataloguing record. Libraries may wish to sub- divide the general term Watermarks by the images they portray. For example: 655 Watermarks (Paper) |x Lion. |2 rbpap
CONCEPT.BT: Paper features (Gathering term; do not assign)
Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for sheets with uneven, random distribution of fibers, yielding a mottled appearance on look-through.
Use for long grain-direction ridges in the surface of the sheet.
Use for translucent, hard, brittle papers.

CONCEPT.BT: Types of paper by fiber patterns
Types of paper by uses or names
Types of paper by uses or names

CONCEPT.SN: Use for paper or vellum treated to enable erasure and intended for use with a metal stylus.
